awd_titl_txt: 32nd International Vacuum Nanoelectronics and 12th International Vacuum Electron Sources Conferences, To Be Held in Cincinnati, Ohio, July 22-26, 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed project seeks financial support for enhancing graduate student participation, at the first joint meeting of the International Vacuum Nanoelectronics (IVNC) and International Vacuum Electron Sources (IVESC) Conferences to be held at the campus of the University of Cincinnati, in Cincinnati, Ohio, from July 22-26, 2019.  The conferences will focus on vacuum electron sources and applications, from basic principles to the most recent technological advances and include plenary talks, invited talks, contributed talks and posters. They will foster advances in the leading research of vacuum electron sources including theory, materials, structures, devices and their applications, field, thermal, photo, secondary, photo, and photo-enhanced field emission. Emission fundamentals and modeling will be addressed together with consideration of novel materials for electron emission and vacuum tunneling. The physics and technology of electron sources and their applications will also be addressed.  The meeting will consist of a series of three short courses in some of the fast-growing areas in the field of vacuum electron sources and applications, from basic principles to the most recent technological advances. The short courses are expected to help students and other young scientists to develop a multidisciplinary understanding of vacuum device research. The technical program will provide student participants with the opportunity to gain exposure to new materials and devices for vacuum electronics, their basic physics, and their engineering applications.  Exposing the next generation of researchers to these important disciplines is critical for learning how the new science and technology of vacuum nanoelectronics are developing. Students will gain exposure to the new advances in material growth, fabrication technology and device physics. The meeting will include three short courses which will be offered to all attendees as part of their registration. A collection of selected papers will be published in the Journal of Vacuum Science and Technology B. The information will be disseminated through the conference proceedings and the journals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The first Joint meeting of the 32nd International Vacuum Nanoelectronics Conference (IVNC) and the 12th International Vacuum Electron Sources Conference (IVESC) was held from July 22-26, 2019 on the University of Cincinnati (UC) campus and was co-chaired by Marc Cahay (Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at UC) and Kevin L. Jensen (Materials Science & Technology Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington DC).

 

Although the IVNC has been historically concentrated on field emission, and the IVESC on thermionic emission, in recent years both conferences have opened to both venues as well as other emission physics and applications and therefore increasingly attract the same participants. The joint meeting started with four tutorials on the first day of the conference: (1) Modeling electrostatic field enhancement factors in field emitters clusters/arrays: from close proximity to mutual depolarization by Thiago A. de Assis, Institute of Physics, Federal University of Bahia, Salvador, Ba, Brazil; (2) Electron emission calculations beyond the classical equations: finite size, space charge and thermal effects in sharp emitters by Andreas Kyritsakis, Helsinki Inst. of Physics and Dept. of Physics, University of Helsinki, Helsinki, Finland; (3) Thermionic and Secondary Electron Emission: Mechanisms, Characteristics, and Applications by Joan Yater, Electronics Science and Technology Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC; and (4) Photoemission: from Einstein to night vision and X-ray lasers by John Smedley, Accelerator Operations and Technology Division, Los Alamos National Laboratory. The tutorials were recorded and can be purchased by to the following website http://www.vacuumnanoelectronics.org/ivnc2019/2018-program/2018-schedule/

 

There were two keynote speakers at the conference: Bernard Vancil from E-Beam, Inc. who gave a talk on 110 Years of Thermionic Cathodes, and Akintunde I. Akinwande from MIT, Cambridge, MA who gave a talk on Vacuum Nanoelectronics: Back to the future or Foreword to the Future? The conference covered a broad range of topics and was organized without parallel sessions so all attendees could participate.  The 112 conference participants hailed from all over the world. The meeting had a total 50 oral presentation covering: Field Electron Emission Physics, Temperature and Morphology Effects in Emission Properties, Thermal Electron Emission Physics, Photoemission and Secondary Emission Physics, Laser Induced Electron Emission, Materials Development and Emission Properties, Emission From Nanotube Based Materials, Thermionic Cathodes, Materials Development and Devices, Device Development, and Device Applications. Most sessions started with a presentation from an invited speaker. The list of the invited speakers is given in Appendix A. On Tuesday and Wednesday evening, there were two poster sessions with 45 and 35 poster presentations respectively. 

 

On the afternoon of Thursday July 25, there was an excursion to the Air Force Museum at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, Ohio. This was followed by a banquet where the attendees were entertained by an Elvis impersonator. Following the Banquet, there was a presentation by Steve Purcell from the University of Lyon, France introducing the next IVNC meeting to be held in France in the summer of 2020, and a presentation by Jean-Michel Roquais introducing the next IVESC meeting to be held in Germany in the spring of 2020. Chris Holland from SRI gave a presentation on the lifetime accomplishments of Capp Spindt who could not attend the meeting but greeted the audience with a video broadcast. Capp was the recipient of the first IVNC/IVESC Pioneer Award which was accepted on his behalf by Chris Holland.

 

During the meeting, a panel of judges was asked to rate the presentation of students participating at the meeting who had registered for the Shoulders-Gray-Spindt award. The winner of this year?s competition was Christoph Langer from OTH Regensburg for his paper entitled ?Semiconductor chip field emission electron source for sensor applications.?

 

The meeting was sponsored technically by the IEEE Electron Devices Society and The American Vacuum Society and financially by grants from the National Science Foundation, the Office of Naval Research, and the University of Cincinnati. The conference was also sponsored by Tech-X, from Boulder Colorado, developers of a variety of scientific software, including physics simulation software and high-performance computing in the cloud, and provides expert physics simulation consulting services in plasma physics and electromagnetics, including photonic integrated circuits.

 

The joint conference successfully brought together researchers and attendees from government laboratories, industries, and universities, enabled their interaction and exposed them to the most recent technological advances in the field of vacuum nanoelectronics and electron source technologies and applications.  The fertile interactions should foster new collaborations and help lead to more practical applications in the field.

A total of 34 students who attended the conference received a grant for $288.25 each for either presenting a poster or giving one oral presentation.
